defs.docs: Rust bindings for [libffi](https://sourceware.org/libffi/).

attributes.value: ! The C libffi library provides two main facilities: assembling calls
! to functions dynamically, and creating closures that can be called
! as ordinary C functions. In Rust, the latter means that we can turn
! a Rust lambda (or any object implementing `Fn`/`FnMut`) into an
! ordinary C function pointer that we can pass as a callback to C.
! The easiest way to use this library is via the
! less checking) is provided by the [`middle`](middle/index.html) and
! Building libffi will build lifbffi-sys, which will in turn build the
! which requires that you have a working make, C compiler, automake,
! This crate supports Rust version 1.20 and later.
! This library is organized in four layers, each of which attempts to
! provide more safety and a simpler interface than the next layer
!     automatic marshalling of Rust closures into C function pointers.
!     abstractions for assembling calls and closures, but is unsafe
!     because it doesn’t check argument types.
!   - The [`low`](low/index.html) layer makes no attempts at safety,
!     but provides a more idiomatically “Rusty” API than the underlying
!   - The [`raw`](raw/index.html) layer is a re-export of the
!     a direct mapping of the C libffi library into Rust, generated by
! It should be possible to use any layer without dipping into lower
! layers (and it will be considered a bug to the extent that it
! In this example, we convert a Rust lambda containing a free variable
! into an ordinary C code pointer. The type of `fun` below is
! let f = |y: u64, z: u64| x + y + z;

defs.name: raw
defs.docs: Raw definitions imported from the C library (via bindgen).

attributes.value: / Raw definitions imported from the C library (via bindgen).
/ This module is generated by bindgen and undocumented. It’s intended
/ as the basis for higher-level bindings, but you can see the [C libffi

defs.name: high
defs.docs:
High layer providing automatic marshalling of Rust closures
 as C function pointers.

attributes.value: ! High layer providing automatic marshalling of Rust closures
! The main facility here is given by the structs
! now). These represent C closures of *`N`* arguments, which can be
! used to turn Rust lambdas (or in generally, anything that implements
! `Fn` or `FnMut`) into ordinary C function pointers. For example, a
! Rust value of type `Fn(u32, u32) -> u64` can be turned into a
! closure of type `Closure2<u32, u32, u64>` using
! function pointer of type `extern "C" fn(u32, u32) -> u64` can be
! borrowed from the closure and passed to C.
! The above usage case eliminates much of the boilerplate involved in
! creating a closure as compared to the `middle` and `low` layers, but
! at the price of flexibility. Some flexibility can be recovered by
! manually constructing and configuring a CIF (*e.g.,* a
! [`Cif2`](struct.Cif2.html)) and then creating the closure with
! See the [`call`](call/index.html) submodule for a simple interface
! to dynamic calls to C functions.
! Here we use [`ClosureMut1`](struct.ClosureMut1.html), which is the type
! for creating mutable closures of one argument. We use it to turn a
! Rust lambda into a C function pointer.
! let mut f = |y: u32| { x += y as u64; x };
! Note that in the above example, `counter` is an ordinary C function
! Here’s an example using `ClosureOnce3` to create a closure that owns
! let mut f = move |x: usize, y: usize, z: usize| {
! Invoking the closure a second time will panic.

defs.name: types
defs.docs: Representations of C types for the high layer.

attributes.value: ! Representations of C types for the high layer.

defs.name: Type
defs.docs: Represents a C type statically associated with a Rust type.

attributes.value: / Represents a C type statically associated with a Rust type.
/ In particular, the run-time value describes a particular C type,
/ while the type parameter `T` is the equivalent Rust type.
/ Instances of this type are created via the

defs.name: CType
defs.docs: Types that we can automatically marshall to/from C.

attributes.value: / Types that we can automatically marshall to/from C.
/ In particular, for any type `T` that implements `CType`, we can
/ get a `Type<T>` for describing that type.
/ This trait is unsafe to implement because if the libffi type
/ associated with a Rust type doesn’t match then we get

defs.name: reify
defs.docs: Creates or retrieves a `Type<T>` for any type `T: CType`.

attributes.value: / Creates or retrieves a `Type<T>` for any type `T: CType`.
/ We can use the resulting object to assemble a CIF to set up

defs.name: call
defs.docs: Simple dynamic calls.

attributes.value: ! This API allows us to call a code pointer with an array of
! arguments, using libffi to set up the call.
! extern "C" fn hypot(x: f32, y: f32) -> f32 {
! let result = unsafe { ffi_call!{ hypot(3f32, 4f32) -> f32 } };

defs.name: Arg
defs.docs: Encapsulates an argument with its type information.

attributes.value: / Encapsulates an argument with its type information.
/ In order to set up calls using [`call`](index.html#method.call), we
/ need to wrap (a reference to) each argument in an `Arg`. The usual
/ way to do this is with function [`arg`](fn.arg.html).

defs.name: middle
defs.docs:
Middle layer providing a somewhat safer (but still quite unsafe)
 API.

attributes.value: ! Middle layer providing a somewhat safer (but still quite unsafe)
! The main idea of the middle layer is to wrap types
! respectively, so that their resources are managed properly. However,
! calling a function via a CIF or closure is still unsafe because
! argument types aren’t checked. See the [`high`](../high/index.html)
! layer for closures with type-checked arguments.

defs.name: Builder
defs.docs: Provides a builder-style API for constructing CIFs and closures.

attributes.value: / Provides a builder-style API for constructing CIFs and closures.
/ To use a builder, first construct it using [`Builder::new`](#method.new).
/ The default calling convention is `ffi_abi_FFI_DEFAULT_ABI`, and the default
/ function type is `extern "C" fn()` (or in C, `void(*)()`). Add
/ argument types to the function type with the [`arg`](#method.arg)
/ and [`args`](#method.args) methods. Set the result type with
/ [`res`](#method.res). Change the calling convention, if necessary,
/ Once the builder is configured, construct a `Cif` with
/ unsafe extern "C" fn lambda_callback<F: Fn(u64, u64) -> u64>(
/ let lambda = |x: u64, y: u64| x + y;
/     let fun: &unsafe extern "C" fn(u64, u64) -> u64

/ extern "C" fn add(x: f64, y: &f64) -> f64 {

defs.name: Closure
defs.docs: Represents a closure callable from C.

attributes.value: / Represents a closure callable from C.
/ A libffi closure captures a `void*` (“userdata”) and passes it to a
/ callback when the code pointer (obtained via
/ ensures that the closure does not outlive the userdata.
/ In this example we turn a Rust lambda into a C function. We first
/ define function `lambda_callback`, which will be called by libffi
/ when the closure is called. The callback function takes four
/ arguments: a CIF describing its arguments, a pointer for where to
/ store its result, a pointer to an array of pointers to its
/ arguments, and a userdata pointer. In this ase, the Rust closure
/ value `lambda` is passed as userdata to `lambda_callback`, which
/ unsafe extern "C" fn lambda_callback<F: Fn(u64, u64) -> u64>(
/ let lambda = |x: u64, y: u64| x + y;
/     let fun: &unsafe extern "C" fn(u64, u64) -> u64

defs.name: low
defs.docs:
A low-level wrapping of libffi, this layer makes no attempts at safety,
 but tries to provide a somewhat more idiomatic interface.

attributes.value: ! A low-level wrapping of libffi, this layer makes no attempts at safety,
! but tries to provide a somewhat more idiomatic interface.
! This module also re-exports types and constants necessary for using the
! library, so it should not be generally necessary to use the `raw` module.
! While this is a bit “Rustier” than [`raw`](../raw/index.html), I’ve
! avoided drastic renaming in favor of hewing close to the libffi API.

attributes.value: / Initalizes a CIF (Call Interface) with the given ABI
/ We need to initialize a CIF before we can use it to call a function
/ or create a closure. This function lets us specify the calling

/ The CIF `cif` retains references to `rtype` and `atypes`, so if

/ - `atypes` — the argument types (length must be at least `nargs`)
